clinical_study.brief_title: Training With Brain-machine Interfaces, Visuo-tactile Feedback and Assisted Locomotion for Patients With Chronic Complete Paraplegia
clinical_study.official_title: Training With Brain-machine Interfaces, Visuo-tactile Feedback and Assisted Locomotion for Patients With Chronic Complete Paraplegia

collaborator.agency: the Alberto Santos Dumont Association for Research Support

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research is to compare the effectiveness of a training protocol integrating Brain-machine Interfaces, Visuo-tactile feedback and Assisted Locomotion (referred to as the Walk Again Neurorehabilitation protocol, or WANR), with classical physiotherapy training for patients with chronic complete paraplegia due to spinal cord injury.

primary_outcome.measure: The change of Lower limbs Motor function: ASIA motor score (LEMS) at the ending time point
primary_outcome.description: The LEMS evaluates motor function on a scale of 0 (no motor function) to 5 (full motor function) for 5 lower extremity muscle groups with a 50-point maximum (25 per side)

secondary_outcome.measure: The change of nociception improvement: ASIA pin-prick sensory score
secondary_outcome.description: Testing of a key point in each of the 28 dermatomes (from C2 to S4-5) on the right and left sides of the body that can be readily located in relation to bony anatomical landmarks. At each of these key points, sensation of pin prick is examined: Appreciation of pin prick sensation at each of the key points is separately scored on a three-point scale, with comparison to the sensation on the patients' cheek as a normal frame of reference: 0 = absent 1= altered (impaired or partial appreciation, including hyperesthesia) 2 = normal or intact (similar as on the cheek) NT = not testable The maximum scale is 112

secondary_outcome.measure: Improvement of Walking index for SCI (WISCI)
secondary_outcome.description: The subject is observed by the trained personnel and the WISCI level is recorded on the scale of 0 to 20 at baseline (Baseline WISCI). The subject is observed again at the defined interval (Interval WISCI). The change in score is calculated by subtracting the baseline WISCI from the Interval WISCI, which equals the change in WISCI (Changed WISCI).

intervention.intervention_name: Brain-machine Interfaces, Visuo-tactile Feedback and Assisted Locomotion, or the WANR protocol
